text: The grounds upon which Linnæus would fain have banished the whales from the waters, and as a dragon of the sea, became almost a perturbation.

passages.fragment: The grounds upon which Linnæus would fain have banished the whales from the waters ,
passages.full_quote: <used>The grounds upon which Linnæus would fain have banished the whales from the waters, h</used>e states as follows: "On account of their warm bilocular heart, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow ears, penem intrantem feminam mammis lactantem," and finally, "ex lege naturæ jure meritoque."

Whether owing to the almost omniscient look-outs at the mast-heads of the whale-ships, now penetrating even through Behring's straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and lockers of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted along all continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan can long endure so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether he must not at last be exterminated <used>from the waters, and</used> the last whale, like the last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself evaporate in the final puff

passages.fragment: the waters , and as a dragon of the sea ,
passages.full_quote: "Thou art as a lion of <used>the waters, and as a dragon of the sea," s</used>aith Ezekiel; hereby, plainly meaning a whale; in truth, some versions of the Bible use that word itself

passages.fragment: of the sea , became almost a perturbation
passages.full_quote: Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly gazed aft to mark if any strange face were visible; for my first vague disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion <used>of the sea, became almost a perturbation</used>
